People don't understand how carbon fibre works.  As the name implies, it's long fibres, and those fibres are very strong, but if you push instead of pull a fibre, it's like spaghetti: it deforms easily.  When carbon fibre is in compression rather than tension, much of its strength is actually the resin that glues the fibre together.  In essence, while "carbon-fibre pressure vessel" sounds kind of impressive (or at least it did to most laypeople before this happened), the vessel was in many ways more like a glorified plastic pressure vessel.
The porthole manufacturer warned Rush about the fact that it was not rated to the depths Rush was going to take it.
"The supposed safety depended upon the tensile strength of a material, carbon fibre," goes the common routine.  Two wrong ideas, tensile and material. What was relevant was the compressive strength, and of a shape, the tube, not any material. Different words.  Different concepts: Compressive. Tube. No matter how strong the tensile strength of a tube, you can always wring it or bend it and squeeze the life out of whatever's in the middle.   Tensile sstrength has almost nothing to do with resitance to wringing or bending of the shape "tube."

The issue with the carbon fiber hull isn't that it's loaded in compression. There are composite structures loaded in compression in aircraft applications that Stockton was probably familiar with since he was an aerospace engineer. He also was not the first person to try and build a carbon fiber submarine, and probably won't be the last. The issue with his design was more the magnitude of the stress, a combination of the immense depth he was targeting and the large internal volume for carrying all those passengers, which meant the carbon fiber sections needed to be extremely thick. He probably did not have a good way of detecting and controlling defects in such a structure, and it's probable that even if he was to do so with the sensitivity standard for aircraft applications that it wouldn't have been good enough for what he was trying to do. His response to the concerns raised by that fired employee was basically that the technology didn't exist to perform the inspection he was asking for, which may very well have been true.   Ultimately that meant this sub was at best a test article which if applied correctly could have resulted in real innovation but really had no business carrying actual people, let alone paying passengers. Stockton was also a test pilot, and probably had a mentality towards personal risk very different than the people he ultimately mislead into following him on these dives.

Often mad scientists in tv and movies are portrayed as being, in some sense, smarter than their counterparts that ‚Äúplay by all the rules‚Äù. The truth is that mad scientists are not scientists at all. The rules they skip are the rules which outline the scientific method and which govern standard practice within that field. A scientist may be critical of those standard practices, but a scientist will always work within those rule in trying to amend those rule. Not unlike law, a scientist must present an argument for why the standards should be amended and it is the consensus of the broader scientific community that gets standards changed. This is how actual science happens. Tinkering and working outside the boundaries can be fun, but this process is more like speculation than science. It can be valuable, but it is vital that you have the complete backing of the broader scientific community when we are potentially putting people‚Äôs lives on the line

Remember those infomercials for storage bags that had a special nozzle so you could suck the extra air out with your vacuum? That's what happened to Linnea Mills. She entered the water with her suit deflated and, because of the damaged equipment, she was unable to add any air. As she submerged, the suit constricted around her, making movement and breathing impossible. The load of weights she was carrying caused her to sink too rapidly for her dive buddy (also a student) to aid her. As you get deeper, it takes more and more air to offset your negative buoyancy, so it becomes a runaway train situation. Not only was she incorrectly weighted, but the weights had been tucked into pockets on her suit, preventing the other student driver from simply unbuckling a weight belt to lighten her enough for the him to lift her. The diving company latered tried to deflect blame onto her traumatized buddy for the incident.

'Inherent risk'... Read up on the ALARP / SFARP principal. It's an excellent measure for determining if actions of risk holders were reasonable in situations like this that allows for subjectivity. Deep water submersible diving now has a long history of safety. That safety is due to testing, materials, maintenance, systems and standards. The risk stated by oceangate wasn't really an inherent risk due to the activity, it was a euphemism for the risk due to a largely untested and uncertified design that was pursued for commercial reasons by people who definitely knew that the vessel could not be provided with a conventional safety case and knew that the device was not certifiable, which would effectively deliver the inherent risk. You also can't waive an ALARP system in the context of a commercial operation, to maintain risk at an ALARP level is the sole responsibility of the risk holder. By definition, to require a waiver in the language used by oceangate is an admission that risk is not ALARP. IMO the ALARP principle was massively violated. That line was so far behind them that they couldn't see it. That is surely grossly neglect.üò¢

I don't think the window or the hull gave in. What probably failed was the glue. The carbon fiber tube was glued to a titanium ring with a bigger diameter using epoxy. At high pressure as you have up to 4000 m, carbon fiber will shrink; not a lot but the tube will slightly decrease in diameter. Titanium however will not. Even at 4000 m the pressure is not high enough to make titanium shrink a tiny bit. So the tube wants to shrink, the ring doesn't and the only thing that keeps both together is glue which is now under extremely high stress, trying to keep the tube attached to the ring and thus preventing it from shrinking. If there is only a tiny crack in the glue, smaller than a human hair, water will rush into that crack and widen it in less than a millisecond to the point where the tube breaks away from the ring and then water will rush in at super sonic speed, filling the entire interior within another few milliseconds. Note that it takes around 30 to 100 milliseconds for the brain to even realize what's going on, so you are dead before you even notice that there was a failure.

I would say, historically speaking, on McCallums comment, nobody called the Titanic unsinkable until after she sank cause is made a better headline. Which would you rather read? The claim has a qualifying remark, as far as it is possible, meaning not unsinkable, but built to above the standard of the time and latest technology. The main difference between the Titanic and ocean gates sub is that the ship was following all the safety regulations of its construction and passed all safety aspects before placed in active service.   Titanic was a sister ship of the Olympic, a ship that was already in service for a bit and that showed its resilience of the water tight compartments when HMS Hawck colided with her at the stern.   Now a days we see a lot of faults in the design, but a lot of the changes in design requirements where made because of the Titanic disaster such as the lengthening the hight of the water tight compartment, making a double hull implementation and obviously including sufficient life boats.   The disaster of the ship was a mix of crew negligence and coincidental effects that caused her to sink.   I get the comparison of the ship to the sub, but Titanic was based on a design that had proven its worth and worked, as well as being with in the regulations at the time and aproved by the ministries that upheld these regulations, she was given the green light to do active service while the sub wasn‚Äôt even given the change to be tested by experts.

The statement "Titanic was unsinkable" is a myth. Based on every previous accident resulting in the loss of one of their ships, Harland and Wolff made every step to ensure the Olympic and her ill-fated sisters were as safe as could be made practical.   The watertight doors between the Titanic's compartments had three systems in place: a hand crank right next to the door; an electrical switch activated by the bridge which released the clutches on all the doors at once; and a float beneath the floor which, when triggered, opened the door clutches and let the doors on either end of the breached compartment slam shut.  The bulkheads themselves were safety-designed, too. Every ship H&W lost to sinking did so after only 2 or 3 compartments breached, and water spilled over the tops into subsequent compartments. Titanic's bulkheads reached E deck, which was well above the waterline, so she could survive as many as 4 consecutive breaches and remain afloat. Ironic that the very thing her builders tried to avoid ended up happening to Titanic. As the bulkheads were overwhelmed, water spilled over the tops into subsequent compartments.  Titanic was also fitted with a double bottom, which was based on centuries of groundings. Often groundings resulted in sinking.  While Titanic's 20 lifeboats were above what the BBoT required, H&W had plans for Titanic to carry as many as 48 on her Welin davits. However, because attitudes at the time shifted to ships being their own lifeboat, it unfortunately meant the Titanic disaster triggered the BoT regulations update.

I‚Äôve not gone beyond looking at the 2003 Bill but I think it became Bahamian law in The Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Act 2006.  Schedule 3 of said Bill (if it made it into statute) would specifically have made OceanGate‚Äôs waivers unlawful. This would not surprise me as in England the relevant laws are quite clear - you cannot avoid liability, despite any waivers, if you behave negligently. Such waivers are automatically unfair. This is radically different from the American concept of proving gross negligence before a waiver can be set aside. The whole thrust of this piece and indeed OceanGate‚Äôs attitude seems to be that the world follows American practice in terms of liability.  Choosing Bahamian law as the jurisdiction for any lawsuit seems to come from the practice of using a ‚Äúflag of convenience‚Äù in merchant shipping in order to avoid more stringent employment and safety regulations.  However, the passengers on this submersible were consumers of a service provided by OceanGate and, if I am correct, the waivers they signed were automatically unfair.

"This is to other submersibles what the iPhone was to the Blackberry."  Umm, No.  I was the QA manager for iPhone development and not only was it significantly more complex product, but it was exhaustively tested.  Just because it was easy to use does not mean the product is simple.  The iPhone was not some rogue, thrown together, product; it was highly refined, and we did the work to prove it would perform consistently and reliably - and addressed all concerns raised by the engineering staff.
One iffy thing was the sub's hull was made in three parts (not including the window). Two titanium end pieces and a carbon fiber core. This was a HUGE red flag as differing materials behave differently under stress and pressure. The end caps would change shape at a different rate than the core, so over time this will create stress points that will cut the lifespan of the sub by a huge margin. SO you want as few joins/seems as possible. Deep sea submersible's are cast in one piece for this reason.

I don't know why people keep bringing up the fact that a game controller was used to operate the thing. That is actually very normal. The US military uses game controllers to fly many of their drones and robotic vehicles. And there's nothing wrong with that. These controllers are well-made and are designed to perform the exact function that is needed to be performed. People hear the word, "game", and automatically think it's not a real piece of hardware. "Game" PCs are some of the most advanced and powerful computers on the market, for example. What people should be fixated on is the carbon fiber hull. THAT is what was ridiculous about the sub. I don't know how any trained engineer could possibly think that wound carbon fiber would be a good material for a subs hull. Carbon fiber has good tensile strength. But it has no real strength against crushing forces. The ONLY thing giving the hull any rigidity was the epoxy resin that the carbon fibers were embedded or coated in. Also, when you view the footage of them creating the hull it appears that they were simply winding the fibers around the tube. Usually the fibers would be wound back and forth in alternating directions to give it a sort of criss crossed weave. You don't simply wind it round and round like fishing line on a reel. I couldn't believe that when I saw it.

Engineering Question?  Wouldn't it be a problem to have very dissimilar materials like metal, (titanium), joined with composite, under extreme pressure conditions just because of dissimilar thermal coefficients of expansion and contraction ALONE, as temperature changes rapidly during descent.  You wouldn't have to have a large change in temperature to cause catastrophic failure under such enormous pressures.

Carbon Fiber better than Titanium...? Uh dude,  hate to bust your bubble (probably too soon still), but Titanium has a brittleness caused by temperatures below -200¬∞C. Typically sheet -40¬∞C Carbon Fiber struggles.  CF is also porous, where titanium is rigid and solid, this is why your hull failed before,  microfractures. Real Engineering also mentioned what I believe to be the most damning thing of all, the vessel was only brought to the expected depth once during testing. That single test does nothing to prove whether the vessel would survive the next dive, or the one after that. In engineering, its called a fatigue failure, in which the cyclical load is below the maximum strength (yield stress), but still high enough to cause wear/damage/fatigue to the material.   So, we use the concept of endurance limit, which is the point in which the material can survive an infinite amount of cycling. This number will vary by many dozens of factors, such as material, shape, loading conditions, temperature and more, but is typically 15-40% of the maximum strength / yield stress of the material. For composite materials, its an even harder number to quantify, which is why testing needs to be exhaustive.   That one test proved it was anywhere between 0-99% of yield, and the noises heard suggest it was likely in the upper end of that spectrum. That is clear, without a shadow of a doubt, gross negligence. I say that, because humans have been extremely well aware of fatigue failure, and testing for it has existed for centuries. We have records of firearms being 'proofed'  (Which still happens to this day) in Europe by means of loading several times the maximum powder charge. If the powder charge utilized was four times the standard load and the firearm survived the test, you could guarantee that the standard load was below 25% of yield, and thus likely would have infinite life, or a lifetime in the millions to trillions of cycles.   So for a modern group to only test it to the expected load, and further to only test it once, as their only real world testing of a device that would be the only thing preventing 5 people from be crushed, is grossly negligent. They never had any evidence it would survive the next dive, much less the next ten or hundred or thousand dives. Its a miracle it survived until the 14th dive. Extrapolating that, Id guess the load was in excess of 90% of yield, though thats an extremely rough and unscientific guess.

The way I see it, they definitely should be held accountable because there was so much obvious negligence. Multiple experts and some of the staff repeatedly gave warnings about the vessel. And instead of contacting engineers, they contacted lawyers. On top of that, the waiver kept expressing so much risk yet the advertisement said otherwise. Then as an icing on the cake was the clear mention of how many corners were intentionally cut to "save costs" on something that requires a higher than normal safety standard than that of most things.
Cutting safety corners is always ultimately more expensive than implementing safety. Even if your company or business seems to be doing fine without safety measures, all it takes is time and the right circumstances (circumstances that safety regulations usually prevent). It's like a company deciding not to install fire alarms or have fire extinguishers or accessible fire exits in their building. Maybe that saves some money in the interim, but all it takes is one fire in a decently occupied building for that decision to cost a hell of a lot more.   Rush and Oceangate cut corners to save on costs. That decision led to catastrophe and now they're out of business. Cutting those corners didn't save much in the long run, did it?

Carbon fibre for a pressurised air tank (internal pressure) is fine and is used - ca. 3000 psi.  For 4000 metres of external pressure (ca. 6000 psi) it's generally regarded as unsuitable. External vs internal is key here. The waiver should have pointed out just how unorthodox the construction was.

I think the comparison from The Titan to The Titanic is quite unfair to The Titanic. At the time of construction, The Titanic was indeed one of the safest ships ever constructed, far exceeding safety requirements at the time, and _still_ The Titanic's sister ships were made even safer using knowledge gained during its construction (before the sinking). The simple fact is that no ship constructed at the time could have survived such an impact, and most would have dropped like stones pretty much instantly.  The builders of the Titanic were pioneers of ship design, and they successfully made something groundbreaking.  The people who built the Titan on the other hand had no excuse. They were not pioneering new safety designs, they were just building it on the cheap and calling it "innovation." We already know how to make safe submersibles that can travel to the Titanic, and they added nothing of value to that pool of knowledge.

Hey man, you tell us that law in the Bahamas is based on English common law. Then spend ages talking through various US courts' approaches to waivers. So why bot just call a British lawyer for a very simple answer.... in English common law you cannot contract your way out of a common law duty of care.  For example the rubbish that lots of ski resorts print on the back of lift tickets absolving the company and employees of responsibility for injury or death even if caused by negligence never holds up in an English, Scottish, Australian (or Bahamian) court. You have a "duty of care" when selling goods or services which you cannot get out of.

You cannot exclude liability for death or personal inury caused by negligence under UK law, that part of the waiver would simply be struck out. There's a statute (unfair contract terms act 1997) which just makes it impossible. We don't really do 'punitive' damages, but since the victims were all billionaires that doesn't seem like much of a factor in this case. Normal damages would exceed what oceangate has anyway.

This is just one lawyer's opinion but if you warn in the release that something could go wrong while simultaneously making sweeping statements about how safe the vehicle is, I don't think the release should stand. I really hope Ocean Gate doesn't get away with this. I'm not a lawyer, but I'm familiar with materials science, and the Titan was a disaster waiting to happen. The level to which Stockton Rush cut corners during the Titan's manufacturing and then ignored any and every bit of expert advice was, frankly, outrageous. Furthermore, the fact that he publicly lied about the safety of the sub should (in my opinion) override the waiver. I will also be interested to see how some of his specific lies affect any legal outcomes. For example, he said that the Titan could not be routinely inspected in the same way that most subs are due to the fact that its carbon fiber hull was a heterogeneous material. He said the acoustic monitoring system would be sufficient (obviously not true). Perhaps more importantly, it IS possible to sufficiently inspect something like carbon fiber for things like stress fractures and micro-damage. It's more difficult to do than with a homogenous material (like steel), but it's certainly possible. As a professional safety consultant (in aviation), I winced at the statement that risks cannot be eliminated, because I so often hear "it's either safe or it's not. In safety management, a risk is some combination of likelihood and severity of harm, and, although we always check, it can hardly ever be eliminated (pretty much only by doing something completely different - in this case, to *eliminate* the risk I would have proposed remotely watching footage from an unmanned submersible instead). If you're determined to go ahead anyway then we can manage risk by managing likelihood and severity, and they're usually both continuous. That means there's no obvious cut-off point between "safe" and "unsafe"; there's a sliding scale from "sure, why not" (slight chance of a stubbed toe, perhaps) to Hell, no! (almost certain death). Suggesting they're equivalent because the former hasn't *completely* eliminated the risk is either incompetent or disingenuous.

This waiver won't hold up for the simply reason that it's more or less the only way to reach the Titanic wreck for a citizen. The Titanic wreck has a great deal of personal significance to many Americans and Britons because they had ancestors on the ship. It may not be an "essential service" precisely, but being able to access a historical site important in the lives or deaths of their ancestors is considerably more important than someone's right to participate in a sport.
Note that there is *no* "organisation that manages the titanic wreckage site". It's international waters and a memorial wreck. There's no such thing. RMS Titanic Inc has recovered many hundreds of artefacts from the wreck, but with no-one's authority or particular ownership endowed, only international salvage laws.

In other words, something that would be a guaranteed suicide in a sub that would reach deformation depth just once - the guy did 14 times before it finally gave in. Just looking at this from a distance you can see multiple serious flaws in this guy‚Äôs (OceanGate) thinking.  First of all, the likely failure mechanism is going to be dynamic buckling, which doesn‚Äôt give any warning and is non-linear.  It‚Äôs not like inspecting an airplane wing for cracking, knowing the rate of crack growth or perhaps monitoring deflection knowing the maximum allowable stresses.  Dynamic buckling just happens...you exceed the dimension/material limits and it just collapses.without any meaningful warning (like bending a hollow straw until it just folds all at once).  Second is mating the titanium shell to the carbon fiber...reminds me of the shuttle disaster (not dissimilar materials but poor lip design).  Under extreme temperature changes and pressure that was a disaster waiting to happen.  And that‚Äôs without considering the porthole window or the funny tail section (haven‚Äôt seen any detail on that composition yet, but it‚Äôs really scary too).  Focusing on silly stuff like the controllers isn‚Äôt the big deal IMO...but the structure absolutely is.  So are the many lacking failsafes or emergency measures that could have been employed but weren‚Äôt. For virtually all of the passengers, the "gross negligence" issue is the big one, and I'm grateful for your deep dive into it here. But a secondary question that looms for me is the signature of young Suleman Dawood, the son of billionaire passenger Shahzada Dawood, who was only 19 at the time of his death and was reportedly "terrified" prior to the expedition, which he undertook as part of a Father's Day adventure with his Dad.  The age of majority for things like providing consent on a waiver is a bit of a tangle under Bahamian law. I think the "Minors Act" enacted around 1976 lowered the age from 21 to 18, which (unless Suleman signed the waiver more than a year before the trip, which seems unlikely) sounds like it would give him capacity to sign his own waiver. But the circumstances of the trip, combined with the specifics of his relationship with his father, leave me with serious questions as to whether he signed the waiver under duress.  A quick look down the rabbit-hole of signing "under duress" opens up other factors that might make a waiver signature unenforceable due to duress:  (1)misrepresentation (i.e. OceanGate or any of its published materials or employee statements were dishonest); (2)nondisclosure (i.e. material information that was not disclosed, which was known to the company and could not have been discovered easily by the passengers); (3)Unconscionability (i.e. obvious unfairness which might even include language inequalities affecting the parties' power to negotiate, in the case of the Dawoods whose first language might not have been English); (4)Public Policy (the Bahamas may have valid reasons to prevent travelling billionaires from relying on their legal system as a loophole to escape the liability of their own countries); (5)Mistakes "in law" that may have a serious impact on the aggreement.  What are your thoughts on arguments that duress could be used to invalidate the waiver‚Äîeither under the obvious layman's definition, that a teenage boy desperate to please his rich absentee father may have signed under pressure from Dad, or under the more highly technical definitions of duress that a skilled litigator would have to build a complex analysis for?

I was/am an HSE engineer. And I said it before, the sentence "the vast majority of marine accidents are a result of operator error" is such an insidious thing to say or at least a huge cop out and may even display gross negigence.  It shows that they  a) have no idea what they are talking about (surviver's and confirmation bias) b) have little regards for saftey c) (most of the time) are thinking they are above the experts in the field. d) think others are too stupid to know better.  He is not wrong when he says most accidents happen due to human error. However that is not because humans are stupid or the sturctures are so strong by default, but because saftey protolcolls are written in a way, that if operation is within those parameters the material/machine wont fail. This also goes side by side with the "oh materials can withstand so much more than what they are tested for". This is also correct, but we test for endurance and SAFE operation. Yea I can push the material to a lot more than what I've tested it for BUT then it becomes unpredictable. So when someone says it's all down to human error, they are correct in the statistical sense but wrong with respect to the actual operation of a machine/material/organisation.  AND ironic enough, failiure here was due to a human error, if you want to make the point. The human error beeing not to acknowlage limitations of their own craft. Yes the material (most likely) gave way, but considering the operation (which I as an HSE-engineer did, I was not tasks with testing but operational saftey), it was human error, discarding of saftey protocols which led to the accident. Not all human errors are breaking wrongly or puishing the wrong button, most of the time it is not follwoing set saftey protocolls, because one knows better and loss of respect for the enviroment one works in.   TL;DR Ironically enough, he is correct when saying most accidents happen due to human error, then turning around and makeing a human error with respect to operational saftey. He operated his craft outside of it's safe operational setting, and that is the most common human error. Discarding saftey protocoll, not pushing the wrong button or beeing to brutish with the material.

Unfortunately they will not get as much as they hope to.  This company's only business is submersible tourism.  They are now officially out of business.  A company's value includes it's tangible assets such as real estate and equipment, cash on hand (bank accounts, petty cash etc. and by law payroll comes first) and the biggest portion of it's value is based on the company being a going concern.  An example of what I am talking about is say a business has $100,000 in equipment but has $1,000,000 in annual revenue with $250,000 of that being it's profit.  Typically though not always, one would multiply the profit by 10 to get a company's saleable value, what it's stock would be worth.  In this example, the company is worth about $2,500,000.  But the moment a company goes out of business then the tangible assets constitute it's only actual value or assets.  So in this example, that $2,500,000 company is now worth $100,000.  Of course some company's have other things that may contribute value for example a customer list.  If the above business is a landscaping business and it's equipment is a few used trucks, trailers, lawn mowers and other tools and equipment and everything else is rented then you can auction off the equipment and then try to sell the customer list.  But in the case of this submersible business there would be no customer list.  I have no idea of the value of all the equipment but any that custom made specialized for this business will be worth very little other than as scrap.  Most particularly surviving submersible(s).  Absolutely no one will every trust anything made by this company as safe so basically all one can do now is force the auction of equipment.  There is a ship and manufacturing equipment.  I'm going to go out on a limb and say that the business was worth perhaps $50,000,000 before all this happened and today is probably worth closer to about $10,000,000 and probably half of that is in the ship.  Of course I don't know how much of that is borrowed.  If they owed say $20,000,000 to a bank then the company would, after a lawsuit, likely declare bankruptcy and all the creditors, including winning plaintiffs would have to get in line.   I don't know who gets priority for the liquidation of assets other than there simply won't be enough to go around and I predict that at best plaintiffs will in the end get no more than about 5 cents on the dollar for any lawsuit assuming each plaintiff limits themselves to just a few million each.   As far as the owner being a billionaire is concerned (I don't know that he is but have heard some reports saying he was), if this company was set up correctly, his heirs won't be touched other than this one company being decimated.  Though, it is also possible that his estate could be sued and that could affect his heirs.
It would be really interesting to find out what Bahamian law allows in terms of waivers and it wouldn't surprise me if the waiver didn't work at all. As you mentioned, Bahamian law is based on UK law, but also its final court of appeal is the UK Supreme Court, sitting as the Privy Council (and I know how colonial that is, not justifying it, just pointing it out). The UK courts are unsympathetic to these types of waivers, mostly because for nearly fifty years we have had statute that invalidates waivers for death of personal injury due to any level of negligence (s2 of Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977), so the waiver would be irrelevant in the UK, and the same might well be true in the Bahamas.

Having studied the Titanic disaster for years, there are some errors in the video I must correct.  First, WSL never *billed* that or any ship as 'unsinkable'. The specific quote in one paper was from an unspecified representative who could have been any shipwright at Harland & Wolff or any sailor or secretary of the WSL. The phrasing was "as unsinkable as we know how to make it" which is very different. No sailor or shipbuilder would ever dare call a ship unsinkable. That's tempting the sea. Secondly the watertight bulkheads were an asset, not a flaw. They didn't close at the top because they didn't need to. They went higher than necessary for the amount of damage the ship could have otherwise survived. Even if they were sealed off the ship would still sink with the six forward compartments breached. When the RMS Titanic was afloat it was the largest ship in the world by a few tons and the only arguably safer ship was her sister Olympic, and only then because she was worn in and the crew had learned her quirks. If you were in 1912 and wanted to have a safe transatlantic crossing your best bet was the Olympic-class. These ships had cutting edge safety features and were built extremely well. Suing WSL for the sinking is not justified because the company did everything it could to build a good ship with the technology of the day, however suing them for their reaction to the sinking is absolutely justified. It's like suing New York City because the World Trade Center fell down or the Fukishima Nuclear Power company for that tsunami. The damage well exceeded reasonable expectations and nothing could have stopped it.

I can't say I'm familiar with Bahamian law, but if it's based on British common law it's likely OceanGate are screwed. Because in countries that follow the British legal model, "liability waivers" generally _don't_ protect the issuer against a claim that they breached their duty of care, or failed to take _reasonable_ steps to ensure the safety of the participant that signed the waiver. This is definitely the case in the UK, Canada, and Australia... the situation is slightly more complex in New Zealand because of the way their accident compensation system works.
Why would anyone pay 250,000 USD for something that requires you to sign a waiver if anything bad happens to you for whatever stupid reasons is beyond me...

Carbon fiber composite are used for beams on airplanes etc.  A beam has compression loads on one side and tension loads on the other.  Clearly carbon fiber composites can carry compression loads.   the issue is that the epoxy always develops cracks.   Pressure vessels that contain pressurized fluids the carbon fiber is under tension. The strength of the fiber to contain the pressure is independent of the bond between the fiber and the epoxy.   The radial stress normally goes from the fluid pressure on one face to atmospheric on the other.  So fluid infusion into cracks moves the radius of the high pressure closer to the radius of the low pressure.  For fibers under compression the fluid can increase the gap between the now unbonded surface allowing for buckling and breaking of the fiber and further increasing the gap and stress in the epoxy.   Fluid infusion into cracks for a vessel with the fibers in tension will expand the gap but the fiber is still in tension and it radius is only changed by the change it stress due to this internal pressure. This vessel will fail or has so many connected cracks that it will not contain the fluid.  Diffusion of  through metal pressure vessels happens.  Aluminum dive tanks thickness is increased to reduce diffusion.
Wouldn't it also be the case that in people's minds there is a severe inflation going on about waivers in general? As a result of frivolous lawsuits which the legal system allowed to happen and even encouraged, there are now waivers routinely issued and signed for the most benign of activities... You let your kid go on a school trip:  sign a waiver.  It's become ubiquitous and expected.  So the combination of the CEO laughing it off and saying it's safer than crossing the street, while having a really far reaching waiver would by some people be interpreted as the same as going on a school trip.  So, the system of waivers and frivolous lawsuits for any (minor) mishap needs reconsidering.

As a mechanical engineer, just saying that carbon fiber is "better" than titanium boggles my mind. In what context!? Compressive? In tension? Are you static loading the material? Dynamically loading? What temperature? There are so many factors that can effect material properties. Fiber glass and wood have different properties based on grain or fiber directions and directional loading. Carbon fiber may be "better" in some contexts, but worse in others. Ductility and hardness are not the same, and are often inversely proportional. Did they think that the hardness of carbon fiber was "better" than titanium?  It is Its all contextual, and it this case it matters! Also, if the sub was designed for certain performance factors, then taking beyond those specifications repeatedly, of course it was going to fail! Just insane...

Anyone interested in learning about the science should look at the thunderf00t videos on the sub. He was amazed it made any successful dives at all, due to how bad the design was (ignoring basic principals of deep sea submersibles, using cheaper, inferior materials). While he only guessed at the cause, his guess is that the shape of the sub is what did it in. Most deep sea subs are basically spheres, at least the part where the human sits, but this was a tube, and the caps were made of a different material from the tube part attached only by some glue, so when the sub was subjected to extreme temperatures, which meant the materials expanded/contracted at different rates, it would pull apart the glue. Just one pinhole leak would have been enough to doom everyone in under a second.

D.O.S.A?   You mean the Department of Statistical Anomalies?
The regulations are NOT why ocean vessel innovation hasn't grown. It's that the depth pressure and humans do NOT mix. That's why space innovation is easier. There's ZERO gravity out there. Under the sea, well...there's more and more pressure the deeper you go (more pressure from outside the deeper you go). It's a matter of inviting something that can withstand that pressure. People ARE working on those innovations but it's a slow process BECAUSE of the pressure at those depths and the FACT that HUMANS die at that depth. We're fragile little beings. A blobfish can withstand the pressure but when you bring it up to our regular atmosphere (gravity & pressure), they turn squishy (blobby). They look a lot different in their natural depths. Anytime you have several pieces of something put together--making joints--you start having issues with weak points (the joints) the deeper you go. The deeper the weaker. It's just simple physics. Pressure and joints equals weakness. That's why so many subs are cylindars with minimum of exterior joints. Many rov's are more round. A lot of experimental subs are orbs/round with minimum joints and viewing windows are a luxury. That's why MOST have external cameras to show you what's outside and NOT "viewing" windows at those depths.

Though such proceedings don‚Äôt always operate under English law ‚Äì e.g. if the court decides Bahamian law is applicable, then it will consider the relevant questions of Bahamian law as questions of fact in English law (and hear expert evidence in the usual way) but that is subject to caveats in respect of positions that would be unconscionable or contrary to public policy in English law.

It feels like there is enough here to demonstrate gross negligence. At various levels, that should open them up to liability.   There is also evidence that Oceangate exploited loopholes, which can be doubled edged, especially in common law countries where judges can have some quite significant powers to establish precedent - for example, agreeing with a lawyer representing the families of the deceased asserting that an organization that takes proactive steps to avoid regulatory scrutiny, which misrepresents its product, and which has a history of dismissing personnel who flag safety concerns cannot be reasonably protected by a waiver between parties, as the company is not a good faith actor, and as such, the waiver cannot accurately convey the risks involved. I feel like this is a space for a lawyer to draw both on case law, but also to synthesis an argument about fairness and good-faith practices.  And, if the waiver that passengers signed clearly does not comport with Oceangate's claim that the passengers were specialists then there is also a good risk, it feels, of the waiver being thrown out. The civil liability is also separate from the criminal liabilities. As pointed out, there are many jurisdictional complications. But, while international frameworks encourage a single primary jurisdiction to be pursued (Usually defined, if I recall, in order of: territoriality, flag, nationality of the victim, then nationality of the accused) there is nothing which prevents the nations whose nationality the passengers held from pursuing individual criminal complaints around manslaughter, conspiracy, etc.

So let me see if I understand. Negligence levels depend on the gap between probability of event understood by customer and real probability? And if the gap is deemed wide or narrow that makes the difference between waive being useful or not as a legal tool?  I would say that this probability gap approach is not the right one, as it based a decision on an approach that had non statistical bias, so the whole case is biased.   There is something called "bayesian trap" which uses Bayes theorems to mislead people. Imagine that you wake up every day and measure the occurrence of a planet killer asteroid impact.  You conduct that statistical experiment for 10 years and still no impact. So you conclude that the probability of impact is zero. Is that probability correct?  Such impact is a rare occurence and the sample size does not provide enough data to tell if there is risk or not.  What do you do then?  You see the sky to see if there is an asteroid coming.  That way you can be certain if there is risk or not.  So in a few words, lack of data (bayesian trap) does not mean lack of evidence that a problem exists.  You need to physically inspect the source of the problem. Also lack of data means that risk can be confused with familiarity.  This case is similar to the destruction of Space Shuttle Challenger.  You have 2 rings attached, and extreme cold causes seals that glue the pieces together, to leak. In the case of Challenged SRB rings it was the wieldings that failed as combustion material pushed through material that was shrinking. And in the case of the sub you did not have wieldings but epoxic glue.  Unlike wieldings, glue can have more or less grip depending on the material. For example, school glue has strong grip on paper, but not plastic.  If you see when the titanium ring was recovered, there was no deformation indicating the glue had a grip on the metal, and there were no remnants of glue attached, which makes me believe the hypothesis of the glue losing grip and detaching from the titanium ring.  Unlike wielding, glue just stops having grip, so it slips away.  Studying the similarities in the design of SRBs and how the fixed the problem can lead you to understand why it is a similar case.  The original SRB had a U cross section design.  So you fit the other ring inside the U shape and then wield the internal and external sides of the U shape to form 2 seals. In the fixed design the SRBs had an N shape which is equal to inverted U shapes next to each other. And there were 3 seals. 2 in the sides and one in the middle.

The design flaw of the Titanic wasn't just that the watertight bulkheads extended just 10 feet above sea level, it was also that it lacked a double hull, which could have acted as a container for the incoming water, without spilling into the rest of the ship. Such modifications were implemented to the Titanic's near IDENTICAL sister ship, the RMS Olympic, making her far safer than the Titanic (with the addition of lifeboats for everyone). Another flaw, albeit of construction, not design was the fact that the rivets used to secure the steel plates in the bow (as well as the stern of the ship) were made of wrought iron, which contained impurities that weakened the overall strength of the hull in the bow (where the iceberg hit). It is safe to assume that had steel rivets been installed in the bow of the ship, the damage caused by the iceberg would be far less catastrophic.

The R2-D2 replica building community uses PS3 controllers a lot.  They're cheap (or at least used to be), Bluetooth enabled, and it's easy to tell a microcontroller or computer what each button is doing.  As a group, though we strongly recommend having a "kill switch" if you're using anything other than a proper radio controller, because all of the other options can abruptly stop responding, resulting in a "runaway droid" - that is, a droid that's in motion but not responding to the controller any longer.  I've even had it happen myself.  So, the entire idea of using a PS3 controller to run an actual *vehicle* carrying passengers into a hazardous situation seems incredibly foolish...

In Australia, a liability waver is not classified as a legitimate document and all companies are required to obey all safety laws and regulations. If any company doesn't comply with the regulations regarding safety, they are always classified as being at fault regardless of the actions of the person who was injured or killed. Even if all safety regulations have been met, the company is still liable for any injury or death. The only reason companies in Australia have people sign a waiver is in hope that they or their families won't take them to court.

If you hear a pop in a submersible, you surface immediately. You should never, EVER hear a pressure differential in the structure of your vessel. If you do, that means something failed and more pressure is being applied to an underlying system that wasn't designed to withstand that same level of pressure. It isn't metal settling to pressure, it's metal FAILING and creating faults due to pressure. In the case of a carbon fiber hull, if you heard any popping, you should just wish your children well and say goodbye. There's nothing stopping the catastrophic failure of carbon fibers because once one starts to falter, the rest follow with it like threads being torn in a jacket. That's why it's called carbon FIBER.

At 4:10, the fact that the actual harm inflicted was enumerated in the waiver makes it obvious that it was foreseeable.  The fact that the vessel was not certified leaves the entire liability with OceanGate and not shared with any certification organization.  The fact that US citizens were killed opens the Bahamas judicial and political bodies up to our federal government's duty to protect these citizens as specified in the US Constitution and further mandated by federal law.  Some contracts simply cannot be enforced by government -- one related example is a contract to kill a human... in this case a contract to recklessly risk several humans. Standard engineering practice includes a safety margin of 30% beyond the worst likely case.  OceanGate had the responsibility to test the vessel at depths exceeding 4950 m before taking passengers to 3800 m.  Such tests (plural) to include rigorous evaluation of the hull's integrity between down-up cycles.  Since invisible water currents make it likely, such tests also should include bumping into a solid.  Without thorough records that these tests were passed, I cannot envision OceanGate's liability waiver being deemed valid.  At best, the passengers and company should share the liability about equally. Incidentally, when one direction is in compression, the other two directions (in 3D objects) are in tension (and vice versa).  It is, in fact, possible to weave carbon fibers in a way that sustains the ocean's compression.  I have watched Titan's construction videos where these strategies were NOT employed.  They used the simplest and cheapest layering that even supports tension only circumferentially and not axially.
It is likely irrelevant whether they can be successfully sued or if the liability waiver is legit.  Oceangate likely doesn't have meaningful assets to seize and I have my doubts that they had sufficient insurance given all the other corners that were cut.  Does the estate of a billionaire who has $250k for a trip to the Titanic really want to waste time to get a meager amount from a nearly bankrupt company who's CEO is dead.

I once signed a waiver to go skydiving that tried to waiver negligence. You can't waiver negligence. If the pilot doesn't put fuel in the plane and we crash, definitely a lawsuit. If the tandem instructor packs his laudry instead of a parachute, definitely still a lawsuit.   If the main parachute deploys incorrectly and the reserve also fails, you may still have a case. Depending on the reason for failure. Did a gust of wind tangle the lines? (Foreseeable -- no case) Did someone untrained pack the parachute? Was the parachute frayed and past its lifetime of usefulness? Was there a known manufacturer defect that they should have or were aware of. All still potential cases.  If you get whiplash from the chute opening, or break your leg on a hard landing, those are both foreseeable risks.

I'm not really sure why people always focus on the game controller as an issue. It's not. The US military uses game controllers for things themselves because they're cheap and reliable. There's no reason to reinvent the wheel. The issue with the Titan was that it was wireless. If a wireless system malfunctions, you don't really have any alternatives. (Ie: Losing your connection to the sub's wifi which is a serious enough issue by itself that wireless should never have been used to begin with.) And since a wireless controller operates on batteries, if those batteries run out of power then you're basically screwed. A wired controller would run off the sub's power systems though. The controller itself is by far the least egregious design decision for the Titan.

Naah - this isn¬¥t gross negligence.  There is no "lack of care that demonstrates reckless disregard for the safety or lives of others" here. The (co) CEO himself was on the trip and believed in his own idea so much that he died for it. If it had been an obvious sham, he wouldn't have been there. The vessel can be considered seaworthy since similiar trips have been successful. Yes, industry experts think the vessel is unsafe, but that is not the same as reckless disregard. It has to be something that deviates from what a reasonable person would do and joining this trip (who hasn't had any "major" accidents before - all those things mentioned still resulted in a successful dive or an aborted dive where no one died) is risky, but far from certain death. A reasonable person might do risky things - for example make a dive from a cliff into a mass of water, despite the risk of possible rocks. You being unlucky is not a sign of negligence. Like say surgery - some operations succeed and some fail. That doesn't mean doctors show reckless disregard if the patient die.    In addition - the vessel was on international water. Therefore there are NO safety regulations that has to be followed (which differ from the diving example since it was based in Montana and all talk about coastal waters does't apply either) and as stated it is very hard to figure out which nation, if any, that have jurisdiction in the first place. US law do certainly not apply. I honestly do not see the potential legal routes that could be taken here. I checked Lloyds for what materials are suitable for pressure hulls. Steel, Titanium, Acrylic, Glass and Glass Fibre were all specified, along with the required quality standards, but nothing on Carbon Fibre. Indeed, whilst Carbon Fibre is used in things like manipulator arms, the only composite material regularly used as a pressure hull material is Glass Fibre but that's never been used on anything diving beyond 1000m, even the Royal Navy's LR5 rescue vessel was certified to only 600m. I actually did a quick calculation based on the compressive strength of Epoxy rather than a Carbon Fibre laminate and came up with a figure suggesting the hull should have been at least 18 inches thick, since the matrix would start cracking at those pressures long before the actual composite started breaking down. The Titan was only really suited for repeated dives to 400m, but then, if you must use a composite material, Glass Fibre would have lasted longer anyway. Trouble is, whilst Carbon Fibre has a higher compressive strength than some other materials actually approved for use in pressure hulls, it also has a really high Young's Modulus which looks good on paper but really means that it's super brittle once it starts to fail, it's powder in an instant, so it would have started breaking down as soon as it reached a certain depth from its first dive onwards. Rush seems to have been inspired by the Deepflight Challenger but that was intended for single use; a one-time flight through the Challenger Deep by Steve Fossett then retirement to a museum. When Richard Branson bought it after Fossett's death, Hawkes Ocean Engineering (who built the thing) actually told him never to use it after he announced plans to offer repeated trips to the 5 deepest parts of the ocean. It was only ever intended to break the depth record and then essentially be thrown away (and that WAS fully pressure tested). The regular Deepflight Submersibles, incidentally, have pressure hulls of Glass Fibre and are cyclically tested by Lloyds to 600m but certified to 100m. The other thing with getting certified is you have to do it all over again every 8 years or so. From what it looks like, although the Titan was theoretically supposed to have a factor of safety of 2.5, it was, in fact, regularly visiting its crush depth and passenger carrying submersibles usually have a factor of safety between about 5 and 10. What's truly baffling is that the first pressure hull showed signs of fatigue so they rerated it to 3000m, but if a certification agency had been involved they'd have rerated it to 0m and said, "Never use Carbon Fibre ever again, you silly, silly man."

Actually, off-the-shelf components, such as LCD displays and game controllers, which have been exhaustively tested in their specific applications can be more reliable than custom built components. The electrionic components used were likely not the problem. Having said that, redundant backup systems, surge, and overload protections are required as are sealed ruggedized chassis. A carbon fiber hull, in and of itself, may not have been the problem either. Carbon fiber air tanks are rated to more than 4500psi and have proven to be extremely reliable. Since carbon fiber expands and contracts more than titanium, the joins where the carbon fiber and titanium meet are enhanced stress points that are increasingly likely to fail after each dive. Likewise, the plexiglass window itself might not have been the problem but the mounting point of the window could be problematic for the same reason. I believe that a reasonably safe submersible could be constructed using such materials and technologies but it would require extensive unmanned testing and multiple iterations to identify and correct problems and establish reliable safety margins. In short, I don't think that the problem was as much about the technology as it was about the lack of adequate testing. Instead of building a dozen of them and testing them on 100s or 1000s of unmanned dives, they built one and put it in the water with passengers. I doubt they even did adequate inspections after each dive to identify possible stress fractures. Since they succeeded, more or less, in 36 prior dives, it is likely that the damage which caused the implosion was cumulative and they failed to identify it with proper inspections between dives. As their testing and safety practices were well below industry standards for companies making deep submersibles, that would constitute negligence.

The thing that bothers me about the waiver in this case is that a customer has no reasonable way to judge the safety of a submersible -- the information is just not accessible or comprehensible to the average person. I used to work for a company that made composite pressure vessels and pipes. One time we took a scrap pipe - absolutely capable of withstanding internal pressure - and crushed it in a desktop vise. Absolutely flattened that sucker. The moment it left the vise it popped back into shape and without knowing exactly what to look for there it passed for unbroken. So not only are composites not a great choice for compression, I doubt that even catastrophic damage would have been evident to inspection. Our products had design features to highlight impact damage. Bet that sub didn't.

Because OceanGate is a Washington entity, a plaintiff can bring suit against it in Washington state. (I'm actually a lawyer licensed in Washington.) The state trial courts (superior courts) are courts of general jurisdiction. Unless federal preemption applies, a plaintiff can bring suit against OceanGate in a Washington superior court--presumably the superior court in Snohomish County, where Everett is located.  Given that OceanGate tried to classify the passengers as "mission specialists," it may be possible for their survivors to claim that the passengers were in fact Jones Act seamen. ("Seamen" is a term of art, deriving from the Jones Act.) That seems a stretch. But that argument could pose a dilemma for OceanGate. If it rejects part of the agreement between itself and the passengers, then it might have to reject the entirety of the agreement, thus taking it out of the waiver.  So I'm kind of thinking that I'd sue in Snohomish County Superior Court, invoking the "saving to suitors" clause of the Jones Act (which permits such claims to be brought in state court).

14:28 If I was a defense lawyer I might try to have this person's comments removed from the record. That videogame controller is being mocked often for no scientific reason. As someone who works with remotely pilot vehicles for a living (walking, flying and submersible), the controller might have been the most reliable part of the ship. Boston Dynamics' robot Spot, for example, was previously operated by a dedicated smart phone game console made in China. This was the main interface for years until technology advanced, and it was replaced by a Samsung tablet that could offer better connectivity speeds with the robot. For the record, this improved Samsung tech was not available when Spot launched as an enterprise product. Removed from context, the controller is just a tool for humans to interface with technology. The prejudices behinds these comments, that the controller was meant for games and is thus inferior, calls the validity of this expert's comments into question. I do not think it would help much though. There are plenty of experts that just comment on the materials used for manufacturing the haul, which IMHO was the real flaw with the ship.

23:05 Shouldn't that kind of gaming of things pretty much remove any protections that OceanGate had?
Gross negligence requires one to reasonably be able to predict the outcome with reasonable foresight in light of codified industry standards adopted by a government regulatory body.   The fact that DSV Titan was an "expermental" vessel and the customers awknowledged that they knew the vessel was not certified and that the law did not compel certification of a DSV along with the knowlwge of the risks generally associated with a noncertified vessel then  prohibits the theory of res ipsa and gross negligence unless Plaintiff can prove that a reasonable person would have expected the outcome under the totality of the circumstances based on risks not voluntarily assumed by the passengers which were not within the passengers knowlege. Simply put, no reasonable passenger would have considered DSV Tiran to be safe and therefore the waiver properly binds Plaintiffs to bar suit.   The fact that Titan had previously completed dives to the Titanic sucessfully without incident would on its face preclude both res ipsa and gross negligence complaints.   Also, given that Titanic was a British RMS and that she sits in international waters, proper jurisdiction of the wreck site and all incidents realative thereto  attatches to England, not the US by reason of the international law of domicile. Therefore this case is due to be dismissed.

Seems like a simple question. If someone signs a waiver, does that absolve a company of all liability for negligence? I would say no. Even when signing a waiver, there‚Äôs still a reasonable assumption that safety measures will be employed. The waiver absolves responsibility in the event of unforeseen disaster, not negligence of what should have been foreseeable safety concerns.

5:24  In this context, instead of an audible sound -- the word crackle may be referring to a specific visible change in the material's surface.   The "crackle effect" can be found in spray paints & nail polish... artists give tutorials on how crackling can provide texture etc.  I think something crackling before it cracks, means a previously smooth surface now looks crackled. So, this would be something caught/noticed during a visual inspection.   This still sounds wildly unsafe but I'd also like an expert to weigh in. A shipowner was about to send to sea an emigrant-ship. He knew that she was old, and not well built at the first; that she had seen many seas and climes, and often had needed repairs. Doubts had been suggested to him that possibly she was not seaworthy. These doubts preyed upon his mind, and made him unhappy; he thought that perhaps he ought to have her thoroughly overhauled and refitted, even though this should put him at great expense. Before the ship sailed, however, he succeeded in overcoming these melancholy reflections. He said to himself that she had gone safely through so many voyages and weathered so many storms that it was idle to suppose she would not come safely home from this trip also. He would put his trust in Providence, which could hardly fail to protect all these unhappy families that were leaving their fatherland to seek for better times elsewhere. He would dismiss from his mind all ungenerous suspicions about the honesty of builders and contractors. In such ways he acquired a sincere and comfortable conviction that his vessel was thoroughly safe and seaworthy; he watched her departure with a light heart, and benevolent wishes for the success of the exiles in their strange new home that was to be; and he got his insurance-money when she went down in mid-ocean and told no tales.  What shall we say of him? Surely this, that he was verily guilty of the death of those families. It is admitted that he did sincerely believe in the soundness of his ship; but the sincerity of his conviction can in no wise help him, because he had no right to believe on such evidence as was before him. He had acquired his belief not by honestly earning it in patient investigation, but by stifling his doubts. And although in the end he may have felt so sure about it that he could not think otherwise, yet inasmuch as he had knowingly and willingly worked himself into that frame of mind, he must be held responsible for it.  - William K. Clifford, The Ethics of Belief (1877)

I guess the purpose of this is to ensure the waiver is enforceable because the resort didn't "force" me to sign it. üôÑ  As if mountain biking and snow boarding are necessary activities. Please... Resort operators are dealing with steep increases in insurance premiums here due to these liability waiver cases. Now, if a resort fails to perform due maintenance on their lifts resulting in catastrophic failure, then yeah, those liability waivers should not protect them from such gross negligence. Anyone who has done ANY kind of machining, manufacturing, mechanical engineering, metallurgy, or even basic materials science would have known about Young's modulus and how different materials compress at different rates under the same amount of pressure. The different compression rates means any connecting joint between those dissimilar materials would never be strong enough and would always fail. Because this is basic knowledge, someone who helped build this thing knew about this major flaw in the design. The fact that it was ignored is proof enough of gross negligence. I mean, differential expansion due to temperature or pressure changes has literally been a subject in the Machinist's Handbook (a really good resource) for decades!

They stand on a circle and hold each other‚Äôs hands as tight as they can. Now a bunch of sumo wrestlers push from the inside of the circle, and try to break free. The rock climbers ability to hold tight helps to keep the sumos inside the circle.  Now we move the sumo wrestlers outside the circle, and make them try to push inwards. Suddenly the rock climbers‚Äô strength doesn‚Äôt help that much anymore, and it‚Äôs only a matter of time until one of them falls over, and pulls all the other rock climbers down with them‚Ä¶  Engineers will probably laugh about the analogy, because it‚Äôs so oversimplified. OBJECTION! Phrasing Titanic's bulkhead design as flawed is arguably misleading, when by the construction standards of the day no ship could suffer damage that would open more than a third of their hull to the sea and stay afloat. The kind of glancing blow Titanic suffered was not anticipated, collisions being most likely viewed as a head-on collision or being struck from the side. The design was insufficient to contain the flooding from the damage, but for any ship of the time the damage was already catastrophic. As for the "virtually unsinkable" claim, this was less an assertion by White Star and more a claim made by others they saw no need to correct, so there is a degree of separation from that angle.

This is a valuable lesson of "Always read the fine print."
Say what you will about any of the other potential hazards, but the fluorescent glow stick and the fact that it was steered by an Xbox controller are par for the course with submersible vehicles. There's nothing weird or unsafe about that. These vehicles do tend to keep their lights off or dimmed to save energy until they reach their destination, and even the military uses Xbox controllers to steer advanced vehicles. They're designed that way with ease of use in mind. That being said, submersible vehicles usually contain echo location devices in order to navigate sans lighting, which the Titan did not. Also carbon fiber is perfectly acceptable to use in a submersible, it just requires extreme precision to ensure that the hull is perfectly round within a plus or minus 0.5% tolerance (I believe it is 0.5%, but  it may be less). From what I understand, OceanGate partnered with NASA to ensure that the hull was constructed properly.  Whether or not it was built correctly, or if the company was truly negligent is not for me to say, it's just annoying that the media keeps sensationalizing parts of the story that are entirely negligible to what happened in the end. They see an Xbox controller as a steering wheel and automatically assume that it's a 'janky thing to do', and then they run with it. People get upset about how easily rampant misinformation spreads on social media, but the media is just as bad about spreading misinformation these days.

Just for the record, Titanic's design wasn't inherently flawed.  She was not a battle ship and was not expected to have torpedoes or mines fired at her.  The criteria for flooding survivability that she was designed to meet were being able to float with any two concurrent compartments flooded (which would cover the case where hull damage occurred at the point where two compartments met from being rammed from the side), any 3 of the first 5 compartments flooded, or all of the first 4 compartments flooded (which would cover the case where the Titanic was in a high-speed head-on collision and had her bows crushed).  This system was perfectly legal and considered more than sufficient to ensure the safety of the ship (and still would be, see below), and in fact the Olympic, Titanic's structurally nearly-identical sister ship, survived a collision that punctured 2 adjoining compartments without sinking.    The prolonged side-swipe at high-speed opening up 5 compartments (strictly speaking it was 6 compartments, but the pumps were able to stay ahead of the water entering boiler room 5 until the water in boiler room 6 started overflowing the bulkhead) was not a scenario that was considered as very likely, and with good reason, it rarely actually happens.  The only other occurrence I can think of that happening off the top of my head was Costa Concordia, where the ship was being handled in a grossly negligent way for no good reason and was being done purely to show off.    The rules governing the ability for a passenger ship to survive flooding are in fact still pretty similar to what they were for Titanic, namely a ship must be able to survive flooding of 2 concurrent compartments (The Costa Concordia collision opened at least 3 compartments to the sea).  It wasn't poor design that sank Titanic, it was poor seamanship.

Hi, it was four people and 19 year old son emotionally manipulated into going for father's day. Please be accurate because you're insult the 19 year old's intelligence.
Bottom line is that SR was an engineer. It can't be claimed he was ignorant of the failure modes and capabilities of carbon fiber composites. He knew WHY they are not used, no compressive strength, great for keeping pressure in. To keep pressure out it's just the epoxy bonding the cfc that takes the load. A thicker hull of pure epoxy would have been stronger and a uniform material that can be modeled and simulated which cfc cannot as it is not a homogenous material with the same strength in all directions like titanium, steel or acrylic the three most commonly used pressure vessel material in shallow or deep sea submersibles. An engineer knows this. Ignorance can't be claimed. That cfc is unsuited is blindingly obvious to an engineer, doesn't matter if it's an aerospace engineer. CFC is widely used in aerospace, so an aerospace engineer is ESPECIALLY familiar in the strengths (and weaknesses) of carbon composites or any composites  like glass composite that is widely used in surface vessels and light aircraft such as gliders.
The Real Engineering video Devon is citing seems utterly damning to me.  And the author has a direct expertise on just the kind of materials used and how they work or fail.  I suggest you watch "The Questionable Engineering of Oceangate" by Real Engineering.  Eagle made a fantastic pick here, but even listening to James Cameron is also enough.  Cameron, despite having fame as a director, has a real and deep expertise in deep sea engineering.    Believe me, RE is being way too kind in the title, but is rather blunt in the video.

I'd say that refusing to inspect the submersible could be construed as gross negligence.
Why the obsession and repeated mention of the controller used to pilot the sub? That's just about the least objectionable thing they did! Controllers have billions of man-hours of testing and development to allow multiple inputs to be submitted precisely and ergonomically, as well as being rather (or even very) familiar to many people. Trying to design an alternative from scratch would certainly lead to a worse solution; the controller is one of the few things who's behaviour isn't affected by the high pressure or the confined environment, so there's no need to reinvent the wheel. As an example, controllers have been used to pilot military drones for years.  Just because some people associate consoles with childishness doesn't make game controllers bad at controlling vehicles.

3:23  The more I learn about the Titanic, the more I learn that this is an insult to her designers.  Titanic's design was flawed, but met the safety standards of the time.  Lifeboats were not generally trusted, and Titanic was meant to stay afloat long enough for another vessel to come to her and her passengers' rescue.  Titanic even had more lifeboats than she legally needed to.  That design philosophy was shattered in the wake of its sinking, and Titanic's sister ship Olympic was later overhauled to be safer, but the point is there was an effort to make Titanic safe.  Not so much the Titan submersible, it seems.
